The U.S. state or territory in which the bridge is physically located, expressed as a standardized FIPS jurisdiction.
The county (or county-equivalent) in which the bridge is physically located, expressed as a standardized location code.
The highway agency level that has primary jurisdiction over the roadway network context for the bridge location (state, county, township, or city).
The classification of the route carried by the bridge by numbering/ownership system (e.g., Interstate, U.S. route, state route, local street, etc.).
The role of the route carried by the bridge within its route system (mainline, alternate, bypass, spur, ramp/connector, frontage road, etc.).
A free-text description of the feature that the bridge crosses or intersects (e.g., river name, railroad line, roadway name, ravine, canal).
A free-text description of the facility that runs on the bridge deck (e.g., the roadway or line being carried across the obstacle).
A free-text narrative describing the bridge’s location context, typically using nearby routes, towns, landmarks, or milepoints.
An indicator of whether the bridge’s inventory route is part of the federally defined Base Highway Network.
The toll context describing whether a toll is charged specifically to use the bridge, as part of a tolled facility, or not at all.
The agency or organization that is responsible for maintaining the bridge and performing routine upkeep and repairs.
The functional classification of the roadway carried by the bridge, describing its role in the road network (arterial, collector, local; rural/urban).
The load model or design loading category the bridge was designed to accommodate (e.g., HS/HL-type truck, pedestrian, railroad).
The presence and type of median on the bridge, describing whether opposing traffic is separated and how (open/closed/barrier).
Whether the bridge width flares (widens) near the ends relative to the main portion of the structure.
Whether the bridge railings as built and present provide adequate safety performance relative to current standards.
Whether the approach-to-bridge transition elements (e.g., rail transitions) provide adequate continuity and safety relative to current standards.
Whether the approach guardrail upstream/downstream of the bridge is adequate to safely redirect vehicles relative to current standards.
Whether the end treatments of the approach guardrail are adequate for crashworthiness relative to current standards.
The bridge’s historic significance status in terms of listing or eligibility for historic registers such as the NRHP.
Whether a navigable waterway is present and therefore navigation control/permit requirements apply at the crossing.
The operational status of the bridge describing whether it is open without restriction, posted with restrictions, or closed to traffic.
The primary type of service carried on the bridge deck (highway, railroad, pedestrian/bike, combinations, or complex interchange levels).
The primary type of service that passes beneath the bridge (road, railroad, waterway, combinations, or none).
The primary structural material system used for the main spans of the bridge (e.g., concrete, steel, prestressed concrete, timber).
The main structural form/design configuration used for the bridge (e.g., slab, girder, truss, arch, suspension, culvert, etc.).
The primary structural material system used for the approach spans, if approach spans exist (e.g., concrete, steel, timber).
The structural form/design configuration used for the approach spans, if approach spans exist (e.g., girder, slab, truss, culvert, etc.).
The feature type used as the reference for reported vertical clearance beneath the bridge (highway, railroad, or other).
The feature type used as the reference for reported lateral clearance beneath the bridge (highway, railroad, or other).
The condition state of the deck element as assessed during inspection, reflecting deterioration such as cracking, spalling, corrosion, or section loss.
The condition state of the superstructure as assessed during inspection, reflecting deterioration or damage in main load-carrying members.
The condition state of the substructure as assessed during inspection, reflecting deterioration or damage in piers, abutments, and foundations above waterline.
The condition state of the channel and channel protection at the crossing, reflecting erosion, instability, debris, and threat to foundations.
The analytical or test-based method used to determine the bridge operating rating used for load posting and safe heavy-vehicle passage.
The analytical or test-based method used to determine the bridge inventory rating representing normal allowable service loading capacity.
A summary structural adequacy rating that reflects the bridge’s ability to safely carry loads considering condition, capacity, and observed deficiencies.
A geometry adequacy rating reflecting whether deck width, shoulders, lane arrangement, and related geometric features meet accepted criteria.
A clearance adequacy rating reflecting whether vertical/lateral clearances under the bridge are acceptable for the feature passing beneath.
A posting adequacy rating reflecting whether the bridge can safely carry legal loads or requires restrictions below legal limits.
A waterway adequacy rating reflecting whether the bridge opening and hydraulic performance are adequate for expected flows and flood conditions.
An approach roadway alignment adequacy rating reflecting whether the roadway alignment approaching the bridge is acceptable and safe.
The type of work action planned for the bridge such as rehabilitation, deck work, widening, replacement, or other structural/hydraulic work.
Whether the bridge requires fracture-critical inspection due to non-redundant tension members where failure could lead to collapse, including any specified interval.
Whether the bridge requires underwater inspection due to submerged elements or scour exposure, including any specified inspection interval.
Whether the bridge requires special inspection beyond routine cycles due to unusual details, hazards, or known issues, including any specified interval.
The bridge’s relationship to the STRAHNET network indicating whether it lies on a strategic highway route or connector important for defense logistics.
Whether this bridge is one of a pair of parallel structures and, if so, which side it represents relative to the inventoried travel direction.
The traffic flow configuration carried by the bridge (one-way, two-way, or special one-lane/two-way operating condition).
Whether the bridge is part of the National Highway System, indicating national-level roadway importance and funding/oversight relevance.
Whether the bridge lies on a federal lands highway route class (e.g., IRR, forest highway, land management system), indicating federal lands context.
The structural deck type describing the deck’s primary material/form (cast-in-place concrete, precast panels, steel plate, grating, timber, etc.).
The wearing surface placed on top of the structural deck, describing the overlay/surfacing material and whether an added surface exists.
The waterproofing membrane system associated with the deck, describing the barrier type used between deck and overlay where applicable.
The corrosion/durability protection system used for the deck reinforcement or deck system (e.g., epoxy coating, galvanizing, cathodic protection).
Whether the bridge is on the designated national network for trucks, indicating whether it serves routes prioritized for freight movement.
The status and condition of pier/abutment protection measures intended to reduce collision or navigation impacts (or note if not required).
The scour critical rating describing the stability of foundations relative to observed or evaluated scour vulnerability and countermeasure effectiveness.
A categorical overall condition label derived from the lowest key NBI condition rating, grouping the bridge into good, fair, or poor condition.
The minimum condition rating among the principal inspected components (typically deck, superstructure, substructure, or related key items) that governs overall condition.
